subsection.title: Elasticity
subsection.p: Real materials react to external forces, as we have seen in the development of the Normal force. If the deformation is small compared to the physical dimensions of the object, many materials often recover the original shape when the external force is removed. This property is called elasticity.

You can see the elastic behavior clearly when you hang weights by a wire as shown in . The reaction force here is the tension in the wire caused by the weight. Initially, the stretch and tension are linearly related, F = k \Delta L, much like a spring. This part is the linear elastic region. If the tension increases beyond the linear limit, we get nonlinear behavior behavir, F \ne k \Delta L, but if you remove the tension, the wire still returns to the original length.

figure.caption: Elasticity of a wire. The wire stretches as weights are added. Initially, tension in the wire and the stretch are linearly related, e.g., as for a spring force, F \propto \Delta L. After some amount of stretch, the relation is not linear anymore, but the sire is still able to return to the original length, when we remove the weight. But if we continue to add more weights, we enter the region shown dashed, where the wire does not go back to the original length. The dashed region is the plastic region. If we continue to add more weights, eventiually, we reach a maximum tension, shown as F_\text{max}, at which point, the wire breaks.

subsection.p: Beyond the elastic limit, there is a region, where wire still stretches, but when you remove the tension-causing weights, the wire is pemanently elongated. This is called plastic region.

If you continue to add more weight to the wire, eventually the wire will break at some point, called the breaking point. The breaking point gives us information about the ultimate strength of the material.

We will be concerned with the elastic range here since we want a predictable linear restoring force to help analyze the equilibrium behavior of structures so as to prevent permanent deformation or fracture.

In the linear elastic regime, the force F applied to the wire is proportional to the elongation \Delta L.
F= k \Delta L,
where k is a proportionality constant. This observation was first made by Robert Hooke (1635-1703), a contemporary of Isaac Newton, and is often called Hooke's law, which states that Ut tensio sic uis, in Latin, meaning As the extension, so the force.
The reason for a material to act like springs can be traced to the inter-atomic bonds in materials as illustrated in , which have a spring-like behavior for small displacement from equilibrium.

figure.caption: The elastic properties of materials emerge from spring-like bonding of molecules inside the material as illustrated here. When a wire stretches vertically, the bonds stretch in that direction, creating a restoring force that pulls on both ends. These molecular forces are responsible for stress in the material.

subsection.title: Strain
subsection.p: There are other types of strain when we have deformation of the area or volume, defined in similar way. We will encounter them later in the book.

subsection.title: Stress
subsection.p:
Experiments show that, for the same force, a wire stretches less if it is thicker. Therefore, the effectiveness of a force to cause strain in a material is contained in force per unit cross-sectional area of the wire rather than the force alone. To describe the cause of the strain, we define a quantity, called stress, which is equal to force per unit area. The magnitude of stress is given by
\text{Stress} = \dfrac{\text{Magnitude of Force}}{\text{Area of cross-section}} = \dfrac{F}{A}.
Note that stress will have direction since force has direction. Even the area of cross-section has an orientation. For instance, the six sides of a cube have different orientations in space. Therefore, in general, the direction of stress is dependent on the direction of the force and the orientation of the area upon which the force acts.

The dimension of stress can be found from the ratio of the dimensions of force and area.
[\text{stress}] = \dfrac{[F]}{[A]} = \dfrac{[M][L]/[T]^2}{[L]^2} = \dfrac{[M]}{[L][T]^2}.
This gives the unit of stress to be \text{N/m}^2, which is also called Pascal denoted by \text{P}.

exercise.title: Stress of the Same Weight on Different Areas

sidebyside.p: A heavy machine, of mass 2,000\text{ kg}, is placed on a table of mass 100\text{ kg}. The surface area of contact between the machine and table is 1000\text{ cm}^2. The table has four legs, each with the area of contact with the floor equal to 20\text{ cm}^2.

statement.p: (a) What is the stress in the table in the region where the machine is placed?
(b) What is the stress in the legs of the table?

hint.p: (a) Stress depends on the area also.

solution.title: (a)

sidebyside.p:
(a) The machine will have to be supported by the compression of the molecular bonds in the table below where the machine is placed. The balancing of the weight of the machine gives us the force,
F = 2000\times 9.81 = 19620\text{ N}.

solution.p:
This force acts over the area
A = 1000\times 10^{-4} \text{ m}^2.
Therefore, stress will be
\dfrac{F}{A} = \dfrac{19620}{1000\times 10^{-4} } = 1.96\times 10^{5}\text{ N/m}^2.

solution.title: (b)

sidebyside.p:
(b) The weight of the machine is now balanced by four normal forces, one on each leg, from the floor. The molecular forces in the legs of the table must balance these normal forces. Let F be force in each leg.
F = \dfrac{2000\times 9.81}{4} = 4,910\text{ N}.

solution.p:
This acts over the area of contact
A = 20\text{ cm}^2 = 2.0\times 10^{-3}\text{ m}^2.
Therefore, stress in the legs is
\dfrac{F}{A} = \dfrac{4,910\text{ N}}{2.0\times 10^{-3}\text{ m}^2} = 2.45\times 10^{6}\text{ N/m}^2.

subsection.title: General Hooke's Law
subsection.p:
Hooke's law given in Eq. can be written using the stress and strain by dividing both sides of the equation by the area A and introducing the factor L_0/L_0 on the right side.
\dfrac{F}{A} = \dfrac{k}{A}\Delta L =\left( \dfrac{kL_0}{A} \right)\dfrac{\Delta L}{L_0}.
Writing the constants given in parenthesis as one letter Y, we have the Hooke's law for a change in length of the wire as
\text{Stress} = Y \times \text{Strain}
The proportionality constant Y is called the Young's modulus. The unit of Young's modulus is the same as that of stress, i.e., \text{N/m}^2 or Pascal, since strain in unitless. This relation between stress in a body and the strain of the body is a general statement of Hooke's law.

exercise.title: Stretching a Steel Wire - Strain and Stress

statement.p: When we hang a 30-kg block from a 1-mm diameter steel wire, the wire stretches. The Young's modulus of steel is Y_\text{steel}=215.3\text{ GPa}. Find (a) the stress in the wire and (b) the percent elongation.

hint.p: (a) Use definition, (b) Make sure to convert units.

solution.p:
(a) The area of cross-section over which weight acts is
A = \dfrac{\pi D^2}{4} = 7.85 \times 10^{-7}\text{ m}^2.
The force is
F = mg = 30\times 9.81 = 294.3\text{ N}.
Therefore, the stress in the wire is
\text{Stress } = \dfrac{294.3}{ 7.85 \times 10^{-7}} = 3.75\times 10^{8}\text{ Pa}.

The Young's Modulus
Y = 215.3\text{ GPa} = 215.3\times 10^9 = 2.153\times 10^{11}\text{ Pa}.
Dividing the stress in the wire by Y will give us the strain.
\dfrac{\Delta L}{L} = \dfrac{\text{Stress}}{Y} = \dfrac{3.75\times 10^{8}}{2.153\times 10^{11}} = 0.00174.
Multiplying this by 100, we get the percent elongation, which is 0.174.

exercise.title: Weight Needed to Break a Steel Wire

statement.p: How much mass must be hung from a 2-mm diameter steel wire before it breaks?
Data: Breaking Stress of steel = 400\text{ MPa}.

hint.p: Set Stress to breaking stress and solve for M.

solution.p:
Let M be the mass that will break the steel wire. Let us set the stress caused by the weight of this mass just before breaking to the breaking stress.
\dfrac{Mg}{A} = Y_\text{break}.
Therefore,
M = Y_\text{break} A/g = 400\times 10^{6} \times \pi \times 10^{-6}/9.81 = 128\text{ kg}.

exercise.title: Compression of Bone By Weight of a Person

statement.p: Suppose a 100\text{-kg} person supports all her weight on one leg. Assuming the weight is supported by the long bone of the thigh (called femur) and modeling the bone as a solid cylinder of diameter 5\text{ cm} and length 30\text{ cm}. Data: Young's modulus of cortical bone = 250 \text{ MPa}.
By how much is the length of the bone compressed?

hint.p: Convert everything in SI units and then use the definitions.

solution.p:
We first compile the numbers we need in the SI units.
\amp F = m g = 100\times 9.81 = 981\text{ N}, \amp A = \dfrac{\pi d^2}{4} = 1.96\times 10^{-3}\text{ m}^2, \amp Y = 250 \text{ MPa} = 2.50\times 10^{8}\text{ Pa}, \amp L = 0.30\text{ m}.
Therefore
\Delta L\amp = \dfrac{L}{Y} \dfrac{F}{A} \amp = \dfrac{0.30}{2.50\times 10^{8}}\ \dfrac{981}{1.96\times 10^{-3}} = 6.0\times 10^{-4}\text{ m}.
The shrinkage is 0.6\text{ mm}.

exercise.title: Stress in an Elevator Cable When Elevator is Accelerating

statement.p: Stress in a cable will vary if tension varies. When an elevator has acceleration pointed in upward direction, the cable will have higher tension than just the weight as required by \vec F = m\vec a.
An elevator of mass 4,000\text{ kg} is supported by a 1\text{-in} thick steel cable of Young's modulus 150\text{ GPa}. Units: 1\text{-in} = 2.54\text{ cm}.
(a) What is the stress and strain of the cable when the elevator has zero acceleration?
(b) What is the stress and strain of the cable when the elevator has acceleration pointed up with magnitude 5\text{ m/s}^2?
(c) What is the stress and strain of the cable when the elevator has acceleration pointed down with magnitude 5\text{ m/s}^2?

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) Let us firs work out quantities we will need using SI units.
W \amp = m g = 4,000\times 9.81 = 39240.0\text{ N}, A \amp = \pi D^2/4 = \pi\times \left( 2.54 \times 10^{-2} \right)^2/4, \amp = 5.067\times 10^{-4}\text{ m}^2, Y \amp = 150\text{ GPa} = 1.50\times 10^{11}\text{ Pa}.
Since acceleration is zero, the tension in the cable is
F = W = 39240\text{ N}.
Therefore, stress in the cable is
\text{Stress } = \dfrac{F}{A} = \dfrac{39240}{ 5.067\times 10^{-4} }= 7.74 \times 10^{7} \text{ Pa},
and strain in the cable is
\dfrac{\Delta L}{L} = \dfrac{\text{Stress}}{Y} = \dfrac{7.74 \times 10^{7} }{1.50\times 10^{11} } = 5.16\times 10^{-4}.

solution.title: (b)

sidebyside.p:
(b) In this part, the elevator has upward acceleration. The diagram on the right shows the forces. The equation of motion along vertical direction gives
F-mg = ma.
Therefore, the tension in the cable will be
F = 39240 + 4000\times 5 = 59240\text{ N}.

solution.p:
Therefore, stress in the cable is
\text{Stress } = \dfrac{F}{A} = \dfrac{ 59240}{ 5.067\times 10^{-4} }= 1.17\times 10^{8} \text{ Pa},
and strain in the cable is
\dfrac{\Delta L}{L} = \dfrac{\text{Stress}}{Y} = \dfrac{1.17 \times 10^{8} }{1.50\times 10^{11} } =7.8\times 10^{-4}.

solution.title: (c)

sidebyside.p:
(c) In this part, the elevator has downward acceleration. The diagram on the right shows the forces. The equation of motion along vertical direction gives
F-mg = - ma.
Therefore, the tension in the cable will be
F = 39240 - 4000\times 5 = 19240\text{ N}.

solution.p:
Therefore, stress in the cable is
\text{Stress } = \dfrac{F}{A} = \dfrac{ 19240}{ 5.067\times 10^{-4} }= 3.7\times 10^{7} \text{ Pa},
and strain in the cable is
\dfrac{\Delta L}{L} = \dfrac{\text{Stress}}{Y} = \dfrac{3.7 \times 10^7}{1.50\times 10^{11} } = 2.45\times 10^{-4}.

statement.p: A beam that extends beyond its support is called a cantilever. Consider a cantilever of length L and mass M resting and bolted to two supports, one at the end and the other is at a distance D from it.
(a) Find the conditions on the forces such that the cantilever is in static equilibrium.
(b) For L = 30\text{ m}, M = 1000\text{ kg}, and D = 12\text{ m}, find the magnitude and directions of the forces on the beam from the supports.

(c) The bolt provide an area of contact over which contact forces act. Suppose, the area of contact of the bolt at the support at the end be 60\text{ mm}^2 . Find the stress in the bolt for the values given in (b).

answer.p: (a) Horizontal and vertical forces from the left post : F_{11} = 0, F_{12} = Mg\left(1-\frac{L}{2D} \right); Vertical force from the second post F_2 = \left(\frac{L}{2D} \right)Mg. (b) 0,\ -2500\text{ N},\ 12000\text{ N}. (c) 4.17\times 10^{7}\text{ N/m}^2.

solution.p: (a) and (b) are done in . I will just restate the answers here (a) Horizontal and vertical forces from the left post : F_{11} = 0, F_{12} = Mg\left(1-\frac{L}{2D} \right); Vertical force from the second post F_2 = \left(\frac{L}{2D} \right)Mg. (b) 0,\ -2500\text{ N},\ 12000\text{ N}.

(c) The numerical value of stress near the threads of the bolt is obtained by dividing the force by the area.
\dfrac{\left|F_1 \right|}{A_1} = \dfrac{2500\text{ N}}{60\times 10^{-6}\text{m}^2} = 4.17\times 10^{7}\text{ N/m}^2.
